plainExplanation: This is a common offence during traffic jams. While often met with a fine, repeated or dangerous instances can lead to vehicle arrest.

title: Failure to Wear Seat Belt (Driver & Front Passenger)
legalText: The driver of a motor vehicle and the front seat passenger shall wear the seat belts available in the vehicle.
plainExplanation: It is illegal for the driver and front-seat passenger to not wear a seatbelt. This is a primary offence for which you can be stopped and fined. Consistent refusal to comply can lead to further action.

title: Driving a Vehicle Without a Valid Fire Extinguisher
legalText: All commercial and public passenger vehicles shall be equipped with a fire extinguisher which shall be filled, properly mounted and easily accessible.
plainExplanation: If you drive a commercial vehicle (trotro, taxi, truck, bus) without a properly maintained and mounted fire extinguisher, your vehicle is considered unroadworthy and can be impounded, especially during police/MVTD inspections.

title: Driving Without a Warning Triangle
legalText: All commercial and public passenger vehicles shall be equipped with an early warning device (warning triangle).
plainExplanation: Commercial vehicles must carry a warning triangle. If you break down and cause an obstruction without using a triangle to warn other drivers, you are creating a dangerous situation. Not having one can lead to fines and contribute to a decision to impound the vehicle for being unsafe.

title: Failure to Use Warning Triangle After a Breakdown
legalText: In the event of a breakdown, the driver shall place an early warning device at the prescribed distance from the vehicle to warn oncoming traffic.
plainExplanation: It's not enough to just *have* a triangle; you must *use* it if your vehicle breaks down on the road. Failing to do so is an offence that endangers other road users and can result in a fine.

title: Driving with an Unclean or Overloaded Vehicle Causing Obstruction
legalText: A person shall not drive a motor vehicle which is in a dirty condition as to obscure the identification marks (number plates) or other particulars required to be shown on the vehicle, or which is in such a condition that dirt is likely to be scattered on the road or on any person.
plainExplanation: Your vehicle can be considered illegally dirty if: 1) The dirt completely covers your number plates, making them unreadable. 2) The dirt is caked on windows or lights, blocking your view or the light. 3) Mud or gravel is falling from the vehicle onto the road, creating a hazard for other drivers. This is a valid reason for police to stop you.

title: Driving a Vehicle Outside Your License Class
legalText: A person shall not drive a motor vehicle of any class or description on a road unless that person is the holder of a valid driving license issued in respect of that class or description of vehicle.
plainExplanation: Your license class (B, C, D, etc.) is specifically for certain vehicle types. Using a Class B (private car) license to drive a Class C truck (e.g., a Kia Truck, Toyota Hilux) or any larger vehicle is illegal. It is treated as driving without a valid license, and the vehicle will be impounded immediately because you are not qualified to operate it.

title: Overspeeding / Exceeding Speed Limits
legalText: A person shall not drive a motor vehicle on a road at a speed exceeding the prescribed maximum speed limit for that class of road or vehicle.
plainExplanation: It is illegal to drive faster than the posted speed limit (e.g., 50km/h in urban areas). Police use radar guns to detect speed. Extreme overspeeding can be charged as 'dangerous driving', a more serious offence that can lead to arrest and impoundment.

title: Possession or Transportation of Illegal Drugs
legalText: A person shall not possess or transport a prohibited narcotic substance without authorization.
plainExplanation: If illegal drugs are found in your vehicle during a police search, you will be arrested immediately for drug possession and trafficking. The vehicle is considered an instrument of crime and will be impounded as evidence. This is a very serious criminal offence, not just a traffic violation.

title: Dangerous Driving
legalText: A person who drives a motor vehicle on a road without due care and attention or without reasonable consideration for other persons using the road commits the offence of dangerous driving.
plainExplanation: This is a broader, more serious charge than just overspeeding. It covers any driving that is reckless and puts others at risk, like street racing, extreme swerving, or consistently ignoring traffic lights. It can directly lead to arrest and vehicle impoundment.

title: Transporting Unexplained Large Sums of Money
legalText: A person shall not transport currency in an amount exceeding the prescribed limit (or any amount without declaration, if required) with the intention of concealing the origin of the funds or avoiding reporting requirements.
plainExplanation: If police find a very large amount of cash in your car and you cannot instantly provide a legitimate, verifiable reason for having it (e.g., proof of a business withdrawal, sale of a property, bank documentation), they can suspect money laundering or funding for organized crime. The money and the vehicle can be seized as evidence for investigation. You will be detained for questioning.

title: Money Laundering: The Crime of Cleaning 'Dirty Money'
legalText: A person commits the offence of money laundering if the person— (a) conceals or disguises the origin of; (b) converts or transfers; (c) acquires, uses, possesses; or (d) retains property that is the proceeds of unlawful activity. Property may be seized and frozen upon suspicion of being involved in money laundering.
plainExplanation: Money laundering is the process of making money from serious crimes (like drug trafficking, fraud, or robbery) look like it came from a legitimate business (like a shop, restaurant, or real estate). It's illegal to hide the source of any money you know came from crime. Banks must report suspicious transactions, and authorities can freeze and seize any assets (cash, cars, houses) suspected to be linked to this crime.

title: Obligation to Report Suspicious Transactions
legalText: A person responsible for the management or operation of a reporting entity (bank, forex bureau, lawyer, real estate agent) shall report a suspicious transaction to the Financial Intelligence Centre (FIC) without alerting the customer.
plainExplanation: It's not just a police matter. Your bank manager, accountant, or even your lawyer is legally required to report you to the Financial Intelligence Centre (FIC) if they suspect your money comes from crime. They can be jailed if they don't report it.

title: Terrorism Financing
legalText: A person who provides property or funds, directly or indirectly, knowing that they will be used to carry out a terrorist act commits an offence.
plainExplanation: Money laundering laws are tightly linked to fighting terrorism. Providing funds to a terrorist group, even indirectly, is one of the most serious crimes under Ghanaian law and carries severe international sanctions.

title: Freezing and Confiscation of Assets
legalText: A court may order the seizure, freezing, or confiscation of any property that is proven, on the balance of probabilities, to be the proceeds of or used in unlawful activity.
plainExplanation: If the state can convince a court that your car, house, or money is likely from crime, the court can order it to be taken from you permanently, even if your criminal trial is still ongoing. You have to prove your wealth is legitimate.

title: Importation of Prohibited or Restricted Goods
legalText: A person shall not import prohibited or restricted goods unless authorized by law.
plainExplanation: Importing banned or controlled items without proper permits is illegal. This includes narcotics, counterfeit currency, unlicensed firearms, and certain pharmaceuticals. Offenders face seizure of goods and prosecution.

title: False Declaration of Imported Goods
legalText: A person shall not make a false or misleading declaration in respect of imported goods.
plainExplanation: Misrepresenting the nature, quantity, value, or origin of goods to customs is a serious offense. It includes undervaluing items or declaring incorrect country of origin to evade duties.

title: Failure to Declare Imported Goods
legalText: A person who fails to declare goods imported into the country commits an offense.
plainExplanation: All goods must be declared upon arrival. Failure to declare may result in seizure, fines, or prosecution—even for personal items.

title: Smuggling
legalText: A person who imports goods without passing through customs controls commits an offense.
plainExplanation: Bringing goods into Ghana through unauthorized routes or avoiding inspection is considered smuggling. Offenders face heavy penalties and forfeiture of goods.

title: Concealment of Goods
legalText: A person shall not conceal goods to evade customs duties or detection.
plainExplanation: Hiding taxable or restricted items within other cargo or mislabeling them is illegal. Customs may seize concealed goods and prosecute offenders.

title: Incorrect Tariff Classification
legalText: A person shall not misclassify goods to reduce payable duties.
plainExplanation: Using incorrect Harmonized System (HS) codes or categories to lower import taxes is a customs offense. Customs may reclassify and impose penalties.

title: Importation of Hazardous Goods
legalText: Hazardous goods shall not be imported without appropriate permits and safety compliance.
plainExplanation: Importing chemicals, explosives, or dangerous materials requires clearance from relevant authorities like EPA or GSA. Violations may trigger multi-agency enforcement.

title: Importation of Motor Vehicles
legalText: Motor vehicles imported into Ghana must comply with age limits and valuation rules.
plainExplanation: Used vehicles must meet age and condition requirements. Overaged vehicles attract penalties or may be refused entry. Customs also applies valuation standards for duty assessment.

title: Importation via Courier or Postal Services
legalText: Goods imported through express or postal services are subject to customs inspection and declaration.
plainExplanation: Even small packages must be declared and may be detained if suspicious or undeclared. Customs applies the same rules to courier shipments as to bulk imports.

title: Customs Valuation
legalText: Customs shall determine the value of imported goods based on international standards.
plainExplanation: Declared value must reflect the true transaction price. Customs may adjust undervalued declarations and impose penalties or reassess duties.

title: Rules of Origin
legalText: Imported goods must be accompanied by accurate country-of-origin documentation.
plainExplanation: Origin affects tariffs and trade benefits. False origin claims are punishable and may disqualify goods from preferential treatment under trade agreements.

title: Importation of Motor Vehicles
legalText: Motor vehicles imported into Ghana must comply with age limits and valuation rules.
plainExplanation: Used vehicles must meet age and condition requirements. Overaged vehicles attract penalties or may be refused entry. Customs also applies valuation standards for duty assessment.

title: Failure to Clear Imported Vehicle on Time
legalText: Goods not cleared within the prescribed period shall be deposited in the State Warehouse and may be forfeited to the State.
plainExplanation: Imported vehicles must be cleared within 60 days. If not, they are forfeited to the State and may be auctioned. Importers can apply for reconsideration, but must pay all outstanding fees and duties.

title: Illegal Street Trading on Road Shoulders and Traffic Intersections
legalText: A person shall not obstruct traffic or pedestrian movement by selling, hawking, or displaying goods on road shoulders, pavements, or traffic intersections unless authorized by law.
plainExplanation: Selling on road shoulders, pavements, or under traffic lights is illegal. It obstructs traffic and endangers pedestrians. Offenders may be fined, arrested, or have their goods confiscated. Only authorized vendors with permits from local authorities may operate in designated areas.

title: Death Registration in Ghana
lawName: Registration of Births and Deaths Act
legalText: Deaths must be registered in the district where they occur. If the death is expected, a medical certificate of cause of death is required. If sudden or unexplained, a coroner’s inquest and report must be obtained. These documents are submitted to the Births and Deaths Registry for official registration and issuance of a death certificate.
plainExplanation: When someone dies at home in Ghana, the family must either obtain a medical certificate (if the person was under care) or report the death to the police for a coroner’s investigation. The resulting certificate or report is submitted to the Births and Deaths Registry in the district where the death occurred. This process ensures legal recognition of the death and allows for burial or cremation.

title: Police Report Requirement for Home Deaths
lawName: Registration of Births and Deaths Act
section: Registry Procedures for Deaths Outside Health Facilities
legalText: Where a person dies outside a health facility or within 24 hours of admission, the death must be reported to the police. The police shall investigate and issue an inquest to the court, which will produce a coroner’s report. This report is required for death registration.
plainExplanation: If someone dies at home or shortly after arriving at a hospital, the family must report the death to the police. The police will investigate and refer the case to a court, which issues a coroner’s report. This report is needed to register the death officially and proceed with burial or legal matters.

title: Sexual Activity with an Underaged Person (Defilement)
legalText: Any person who has carnal knowledge of a child under sixteen years of age commits the offence of defilement and is liable on conviction to imprisonment for a term of not less than seven years and not more than twenty-five years.
plainExplanation: In Ghana, it is illegal to have any form of sexual activity with a person under the age of 16. This is called defilement. The law applies equally to male and female victims. Even if the minor agrees, the law does not recognize their consent. Offenders can be jailed for 7 to 25 years.

title: Rape Offence in Ghana
legalText: Rape is defined as the carnal knowledge of a female aged sixteen years or above without her consent. It is a first-degree felony punishable by imprisonment for a term of not less than five years and not more than twenty-five years.
plainExplanation: In Ghana, rape means having sexual intercourse with a woman aged 16 or older without her consent. It is a serious crime with a prison sentence of 5 to 25 years. The law does not currently recognize male victims or female perpetrators under this definition.

title: Customary Marriage in Ghana
lawName: Customary Marriage and Divorce Registration Law
legalText: Customary marriage is a union performed according to the traditions of the parties' ethnic groups. It may be monogamous or polygamous. Registration is optional but recommended for legal protection.
plainExplanation: This is the most common form of marriage in Ghana. It involves family consent, traditional rites, and the exchange of gifts. It can be polygamous. Registration with the district assembly is optional but helps with legal recognition for property and inheritance.

title: Ordinance (Civil) Marriage in Ghana
legalText: Ordinance marriage is a monogamous union governed by the Marriage Act. It requires public notice, registration, and a ceremony conducted by a licensed registrar or minister.
plainExplanation: This is a legally binding, monogamous marriage similar to Western-style unions. Couples must give notice at the district office, wait 21 days, and marry before a registrar or licensed minister. It offers strong legal protection for spouses and children.

title: Islamic (Mohammedan) Marriage in Ghana
legalText: Islamic marriage is governed by Muslim personal law and the Marriage of Mohammedans Ordinance. It may be monogamous or polygamous and must be witnessed and registered for legal recognition.
plainExplanation: This marriage follows Islamic rites, including the nikah ceremony. It allows polygamy if permitted by Islamic law. Registration with the district ensures legal protection for spouses and children under Ghanaian law.

title: Recognition of Foreign Marriages in Ghana
legalText: Marriages legally performed in other countries are recognized in Ghana if they comply with the laws of the country where they occurred and do not conflict with Ghanaian public policy.
plainExplanation: If a couple marries abroad, Ghana will recognize the union as long as it was legal in that country. For full legal protection in Ghana, the marriage should be registered locally. Polygamous foreign marriages may be recognized under customary or Islamic law.

title: Bigamy in Ghana
legalText: Any person who, being married under the Marriage Act, marries another person during the lifetime of the spouse commits the offence of bigamy and is liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years.
plainExplanation: Bigamy is when someone who is already legally married under the Marriage Act marries another person without legally ending the first marriage. It is a criminal offence in Ghana and can lead to up to five years in prison. This law protects the integrity of monogamous marriages.

title: Intestate Succession in Ghana
legalText: Where a person dies intestate, their estate is distributed among the surviving spouse(s), children, parents, and extended family. Household chattels go to spouse and children. One house is reserved for spouse and/or children. The residue is shared: 3/16 to spouse, 9/16 to children, 1/8 to parents, 1/8 to extended family.
plainExplanation: If someone dies without a will, their property is shared by their spouse, children, parents, and extended family. The spouse and children get household items and one house. The rest is split: 56.25% to children, 18.75% to spouse, 12.5% to parents, and 12.5% to extended family.

title: Testate Succession in Ghana
legalText: A person may dispose of their estate by will, provided they are of sound mind and at least 18 years old. The will must be signed and witnessed. Beneficiaries may include spouse, children, family, or others. The will overrides intestate rules unless challenged.
plainExplanation: If someone dies with a valid will, their property is shared according to their wishes. The will must be signed and witnessed. It can name anyone as a beneficiary. If the will is valid, it overrides the default inheritance rules.

title: Property Division After Divorce in Ghana
lawCode: Article 22 of 1992 Constitution + Supreme Court Precedents
legalText: Upon divorce, spouses are entitled to an equitable share of property acquired during the marriage. The Supreme Court has ruled that both spouses contribute—financially or otherwise—and deserve fair distribution.
plainExplanation: When a couple divorces, the property they acquired during the marriage is shared fairly. Even if one spouse didn’t earn money, their support and contributions count. The court decides what’s fair based on each person’s role.

title: House Allocation in Intestate Succession
legalText: Where the estate includes only one house, the surviving spouse or child or both shall be entitled to that house. If they cannot agree, the Administrator may apply to court to decide.
plainExplanation: If the person who died left only one house, it goes to the spouse, child, or both. If they disagree on who gets it, the court will decide. This rule protects surviving families from eviction.

title: Child Custody After Divorce in Ghana
section: Children's Act Sections 2, 6, 10; Matrimonial Causes Act Section 16
legalText: In divorce proceedings, custody of children shall be determined based on the best interest of the child. The court may grant custody to either parent or both, considering the child's welfare, age, and emotional needs. Maintenance orders may be issued to support the child.
plainExplanation: After divorce, the court decides who keeps the child based on what’s best for the child. This includes emotional stability, care, and safety. Younger children often stay with the mother, but either parent can be awarded custody. The other parent may be required to pay child support.

title: Right to Parental Care and Protection
legalText: Every child has the right to life, dignity, respect, leisure, liberty, health, education and shelter from their parents.
plainExplanation: Children have the right to be cared for by their parents. Neglecting a child’s basic needs—food, shelter, education—is a legal offence.

title: Protection Against Child Labour
legalText: No child shall be employed or work in any hazardous job or environment that endangers their health, education or development.
plainExplanation: Children must not be used for dangerous or exploitative work. Selling on the streets, farming with chemicals, or working long hours is illegal.

title: Right to Education Without Discrimination
legalText: Every child has the right to education and shall not be denied access to school based on gender, disability, or background.
plainExplanation: No child should be refused admission to school because of poverty, disability, or family status. Education is a legal right.

title: Protection Against Physical Abuse
legalText: No person shall subject a child to torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.
plainExplanation: Beating, burning, or humiliating a child is illegal—even by parents or teachers. Children must be disciplined with dignity.

title: Right to Identity and Birth Registration
legalText: Every child shall be registered at birth and have the right to a name and nationality.
plainExplanation: Children must be registered at birth. Without a birth certificate, they may be denied school, healthcare, or legal protection.

title: Right to Be Heard in Custody or Welfare Cases
legalText: In any matter concerning a child, the views of the child shall be considered if the child is capable of expressing them.
plainExplanation: Children have the right to speak in court about their welfare or custody. Judges must listen to their views before deciding.

title: Maintenance Obligations of Parents
legalText: A parent or guardian shall be responsible for the maintenance of a child including education and health needs.
plainExplanation: Both parents must support their child financially—even after separation. You can apply for child support through the Family Tribunal.

title: Age of Criminal Responsibility in Ghana
legalText: A person under twelve years of age is not criminally responsible for any act or omission.
plainExplanation: Children under 12 cannot be charged with crimes. Between 12–18, courts must consider their maturity and focus on rehabilitation.

title: Juvenile Court Procedures
legalText: Juvenile courts shall conduct proceedings in private and prioritize the welfare and rehabilitation of the child.
plainExplanation: Children are tried in special courts. Hearings are private, and judges must protect the child’s dignity and future.

title: Intercountry Adoption Rules
legalText: Intercountry adoption shall be approved only if it is in the best interest of the child and follows prescribed procedures.
plainExplanation: Foreign adoptions must be carefully reviewed. Ghana ensures the child’s safety and prevents exploitation.

title: Termination of Foster Placement
legalText: The Department of Social Welfare may terminate foster care if the placement endangers the child’s welfare.
plainExplanation: If a foster home becomes unsafe, Social Welfare can remove the child and find a better placement.

title: Child Labour Restrictions
legalText: Children under thirteen years shall not be employed, and those between thirteen and fifteen may only do light work.
plainExplanation: Children under 13 cannot work. Ages 13–15 may do safe, light jobs—not anything dangerous or harmful.

title: Reporting Child Exploitation
legalText: Any person may report suspected abuse or exploitation of a child to the police, social welfare, or CHRAJ.
plainExplanation: Anyone can report child abuse. Authorities must investigate and protect the child from further harm.

title: Accessibility in Public Spaces
legalText: Public buildings shall be made accessible to persons with disability.
plainExplanation: Buildings must have ramps, signs, and toilets that children with disabilities can use safely and independently.

title: Non-Discrimination in Healthcare
legalText: A health care provider shall not discriminate against a person with disability in the provision of medical services.
plainExplanation: Hospitals must treat disabled children fairly. Denying care based on disability is illegal and unethical.
